Graphical abstract Ruthenium catalysts are promising for the catalytic release of H2 from ammonia borane (AB). The reaction kinetics and the role of the support in the release of H2 from AB in methanol solvent were studied using a series of Ru nanoparticle catalysts on various supports (SiO2, carbon, γ-Al2O3, and TiO2). Catalysts were synthesized using incipient wetness impregnation and solution deposition (SD) methods and characterized using N2 physisorption, X-ray diffraction, inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy, CO diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy, and transmission electron microscopy. The reaction kinetics were examined by measuring initial rates using a semi-batch reactor with a constant flow through the headspace analyzed by online mass spectrometry. The Ru/TiO2-SD and Ru/C catalysts had the highest measured initial rates compared to the Ru/SiO2 and Ru/Al2O3. Measured apparent activation energies were relatively similar between all catalysts. Regression of initial rates as a function of AB concentration was done for two different rate equations derived from two different proposed mechanisms for AB methanolysis. Both mechanisms were able to sufficiently describe trends in H2 formation rate versus concentration at low AB concentrations. However, determination of which of the two proposed mechanisms best captures the trends in the data trends was inconclusive due to the lack of a statistically significant difference between degree-of-fit of the two models. Stability tests showed that Ru/C was less prone to deactivation over repeated use compared to Ru supported on the oxides. This study presents a comprehensive examination of the kinetics of AB methanolysis on different supported Ru catalysts; analysis of reaction mechanisms on all catalysts revealed similar apparent first order rate constants from either proposed kinetic models. This study demonstrates that while the support has relatively little influence on the measured reaction rates, carbon may be a preferred support given the decreased deactivation observed relative to the other supports tested. Keywords Hydrogen Ammonia borane Ruthenium Kinetics Nanoparticles Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Solid-state and liquid-phase storage of H2 are desirable for transportation of H2 from production sites to points of use, as these can offer high storage density of dihydrogen and are safer than storage and transport of compressed hydrogen gas [1]. The U.S. Department of Energy’s targets for H2 use in light vehicles are a gravimetric storage density of 0.04 mol H2 g−1, a volumetric storage density of 39 mol H2 L-1, a delivery pressure range of 5–12 bar, and a delivery temperature range of 233–358 K. Ammonia borane (AB) is an attractive candidate for the solid-state chemical storage of hydrogen gas. AB is non-toxic, environmentally benign [2,3], is a solid at room temperature, and has a gravimetric density of 0.1 mol H2 g−1 [4]. Additionally, ammonia borane can form an extremely soluble eutectic mixture with methylamine borane where 30 %/70 % mixtures of the former and the latter has a solubility of 180 molal in methanol. This solubility is much greater than the solubility of ammonia borane or methylamine borane in methanol (8.6 and 29 molal, respectively) and results in a gravimetric storage density of 0.07 mol H2 g−1 [5]. AB has high solubility in a variety of solvents, such as water and alcohols, and is stable as a solid and in solution [5–7]. The AB solubility is higher in water than methanol (solubilities are 3.36*105 g m−3 and 1.82*105 g m−3, respectively); and AB has been shown to not self-hydrolyze in water, while it degrades slowly in methanol [8–10]. AB includes a dative N-B bond; the dissociation of the B–H and N–H bonds are favorable over the cleaving the N–B bond [11]. Catalytic dehydrogenation can be performed at sub-ambient temperatures, whereas thermal release of H2 of all three equivalents of dihydrogen from AB requires elevated temperatures (623 K) [12]. When H2 release from AB is performed in methanol solvent, the methoxy borate species that forms during methanolysis can be recycled, unlike the metaborate species that forms during the catalyzed hydrolysis reaction [13,14]. Additionally, hydrolysis of ammonia borane (in water solvent) leads to NH3 formation which can lead to catalyst poisoning. For example, NH3 formation during the hydrolysis reaction limits H2 selectivity and in fuel cell applications [15]; NH3 impurities at trace concentration can hinder performance, at higher concentrations of NH3 (30 ppm) irreversible damage can be inflicted on the cell during extended use [16]. Supported monometallic catalysts have been extensively studied for the release of H2 via the hydrolysis of ammonia borane, Pd [17], Ru [18–21], Pt [22], and Rh [23]. Previously reported catalyst supports include transition metal oxides such as titanium oxide [20,24], carbon based supports [25], and zeolite frameworks [26]. The noble metals Pd, Pt, Rh, and Ru show high catalytic activity for the dehydrogenation of AB to evolve H2 [27]. Ru and Rh catalysts typically have the highest reported rates among supported monometallic noble metals. The high activity paired with the lower cost of Ru compared to Rh make Ru based catalysts an attractive choice for ammonia borane dehydrogenation [27]. Measured turnover frequencies at 298 K over monometallic supported Ru nanoparticles of ∼ 10.1 s−1 have been reported [24,28], and these catalysts are typically able to remove all three equivalents of H2 from AB [29]. The effect of the support on the rate and selectivity of Ru-based catalysts in AB hydrolysis and methanolysis (Scheme 1 ) is substantially less explored than the identity, size, and morphology of the nanoparticles [29]. Mori et al. [24] compared the hydrolysis of ammonia borane (0.2 M, 298 K) on ruthenium nanoparticles supported on various metal oxides and found that titania supported nanoparticles had the highest measured turnover frequencies (TOFs) among the selection of transition metal oxides (e.g,. TiO2 (P25), TiO2 (rutile), TiO2 (anatase), SiO2 Al2O3, ZrO2, MgO). The kinetics of AB dehydrogenation are influenced by the solvent, as a mechanistic step in the hydrolysis and methanolysis of AB involves the breakage of an O–H bond in each solvent molecule [30]. Catalytic routes in solvents such as methanol and water shown in Scheme 1 lead to the release of three equivalents of H2 at much more moderate temperatures than thermal decomposition routes [12]. The ΔH of the reaction is 0 ± 6 kJ mol−1, which assuming a ΔS of zero equates to an equilibrium constant ranging between 0.1–10 [31]. In kinetic isotope experiments on N-doped carbon-confined Ru Li et al. [32] observed a primary kinetic isotope effect of 5.78 for CH3OH/CD3OD. In water, AB hydrolysis over heterogeneous catalysts has been shown to follow Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetics [33]. It was proposed that the rate limiting step for AB hydrolysis (Scheme 1, Eq. (1) involves cleavage of an O–H bond, on the basis of observed kinetic isotopes when H2O is replaced with D2O as solvent [34]. Measured activation energies on supported Ru catalysts vary based on reaction conditions, catalyst and support composition; values for ammonia borane hydrolysis of 38–70 kJ mol−1 (0.1 M AB, 293–313 K) and 24–54 kJ mol−1 (0.02–0.3 M AB, 303–313 K) [20,24,35–37] have been reported previously. DFT calculations performed on Ru(100) suggest that the release of H2 from AB involves the breakage of the dative B-N bond and cleavage of the O–H bond in the solvent; in both methanolysis and hydrolysis the barrier for O–H bond scission was higher that of the B-N bond scission [30]. Other accounts highlight the role of BH3 group in the dehydrogenation of NH3BH3 (following B-N scission) through the formation of a low energy six-membered cyclic transition structure involving a B-H-H-N interaction step [15]. However, other hydrolysis pathways have been proposed that do not involve the cleavage of the dative B-N bond [18] but instead begin with the coordination of the AB molecule to a Ru(II) site followed by the nucleophilic attack of an H2O on the Ru(II) complex forming NH3BH2(H2O)+ and a Ru(II) hydride complex. The attack of resultant NH3BH2(H2O)+ species on the Ru(II) hydride results in formation of a ruthenium dihydrogen species which eventually releases H2. These steps result in the following stoichiometric reaction: N H 3 B H 3 + 3 H 2 O → N H 3 B O H 3 + 3 H 2 . Prior studies of the kinetics of AB methanolysis are limited. However, Amoo et al. [38] observed that the H2 desorption is rate-limiting during measurements of AB methanolysis on Pd-Al2O3 supported Co-Ni-P based catalysts. Here, we measure kinetics of H2 release from AB in methanol solvent over Ru nanoparticles on a series of supports. We compare initial rates and apparent kinetic parameters across these materials and propose two different mechanisms for the methanolysis of AB on supported Ru catalysts and regress H2 evolution rate data as a function AB concentration data to the two resultant rate equations. H2 evolution rates are compared with deconvoluted IR peaks from CO DRIFTS suggesting the concentration of Ru0 sites is a determinant of catalytic activity for AB methanolysis. Additionally, re-use testing to compare the stability of catalyst was performed on the Ru/C and Ru/Al2O3.The results indicate that the role of the support is to primarily influence the stability of the catalyst and had relatively low impact on the measured H2 evolution rates and reaction kinetics. 2 Methods 2.1 Synthesis Supported ruthenium nanoparticles (γ-Al2O3, SiO2 (Si-xerogel), C, TiO2) were synthesized using incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) to reach a target metal loading of 2.5 wt%. The pore volumes were measured for the SiO2, γ-Al2O3 (99.97 %, Thermo Fisher), P25 TiO2 (Sigma Aldrich) and carbon black pearls (Cabot) by adding de-ionized water dropwise to 0.01 g of the support until the pores were saturated. The mass of water added was converted to volume and normalized by the support mass to obtain an estimate of the pore volume for the support. 2.5 wt% solutions of ruthenium (III) chloride hydrate (Sigma Aldrich) were added dropwise to ∼1.00 g of the support while stirring with a spatula until the solids were saturated with the aqueous ruthenium solution. The wet solids were dried for 12 h in a vacuum oven (20 mmHg) at 313 K. After drying the solids were reduced in a tube furnace (Lindberg Blue M, Thermo Fisher) in 0.33 cm3 s−1 gsolid -1 of flowing H2 (99.999 %, Airgas) for 2 h at 573 K (0.083 K s−1 ramp rate). The reduced catalysts were then ground in a mortar and pestle and stored in a capped scintillation vial before use. Si-xerogel was prepared by mixing HCl (3.4 cm3, Sigma, 37 % reagent grade) with tetraethyl orthosilicate (40 g, TEOS; Sigma Aldrich, reagent grade, 98 %) and Millipore water. The solution was stirred for 17 h at room temperature. 1 M NH4OH (15 cm3, Sigma Aldrich) was added dropwise to the TEOS solution until a gel formed. This gel was dried at 433 K for 24 h. The solids were crushed and washed with Millipore water six times by vortex mixing and centrifugation, until the pH of the supernatant was invariant, and typically ∼5.5. The solids were tried once more at 433 K for 24 h and subsequently calcined in flowing air (1.67 cm3 gsolid -1) at 825 K for 10 h (0.0167 K s−1). Solution deposition was also used to synthesize Ru/TiO2 was also synthesized by solution deposition (sample named “Ru/TiO2-SD“). 1.00 g of TiO2 were added to 100 cm3 of water along with 0.025 g of ruthenium chloride hydrate (Sigma Aldrich) and stirred for 1 h. The solution was covered with an aluminum foil tent while a stream of air was flowed over the solution for 36 h to evaporate the solvent. The solids were then dried in a vacuum oven (20 mmHg) at 313 K and subsequently reduced in a tube furnace (Lindberg Blue M, Thermo Fisher) at 573 K in 0.33 cm3 s−1 g solid-1 of flowing H2 (99.999 %, Airgas) at a ramp rate of 0.083 K s−1. The reduced solids were ground in a mortar and pestle and stored in a scintillation vial before use. 2.2 Characterization 2.2.1 X-ray diffraction (XRD) Powder XRD patterns were collected on all samples using a Rigaku Smartlab diffractometer using a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.54Å). The patterns were measured in a range of 2θ angles from 20 to 80° using a scan rate of 1.5° s−1 and a step size of 0.05. Sample powders (∼0.01 g) were loaded into zero background sample holders (Rigaku) and pressed flat using a glass microscope slide. 2.2.2 Inductive coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) Ruthenium content in each sample was determined by ICP-OES using an Agilent 5800 instrument. Catalyst samples (0.01–0.05 g) were dissolved in HF (48–51%, VWR). Aqua regia was made by mixing hydrochloric acid (Sigma Aldrich, 37%) and nitric acid (Sigma Aldrich, 68–70%) in a 3:1 ratio. 2 cm3 of aqua regia were added to each sample and the mixtures were allowed to dissolve overnight. The samples were then diluted in 2% nitric acid (Sigma Aldrich, 68–70%). A calibration curve was constructed from four calibration standards (0.1 ppm, 1 ppm, 10 ppm, 25 ppm) from a stock standard (1000 ppm Ru in 5% HCl, RICCA). (Note: care should be taken when handling concentrated HF!). 2.2.3 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) TEM images were using a Talos F200i microscope. Samples were dispersed on Cu TEM grids (Electron Microscopy Sciences) by sonicating a small amount of catalyst powder (∼0.005 g) in methanol (Sigma Aldrich, 99.9 %) for 1 h. The solution was then dispersed onto the TEM grid and allowed to dry for 12 h before the measurement was performed. (2) [39], where vm and am are the area occupied by a surface atom and volume occupied by an atom in the bulk metal. 2.2.4 N2 physisorption BET surface areas were calculated by fitting the N2 adsorption isotherm to the BET equation in the relative pressure range of 0.08–0.3. In a typical analysis, 0.05–0.09 g of sieved catalyst particles (180–250 µm) were loaded into a weighed empty sample tube that had been passed through a static gate. The sample was degassed under vacuum (<0.005 Torr) while heating to 393 K at 0.167 K s−1 and holding for 1 h, then the sample was heated to 623 K at a ramp rate of 0.167 K s−1 and held for 9 h. The adsorption isotherm was taken at 77 K following the degas procedure. 2.2.5 CO diffuse reflectance infrared fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) CO DRIFTS spectra were taken using a Vertex 70 spectrometer (Bruker) using a Hg-Cd-Te detector (MCT) detector. The catalyst powders were loaded into a Harrick reactor cell (part no. DRK-5-XXX) and the powders were heated to 573 K (0.083 K s−1) in flowing 10 % H2/Ar (0.5 cm3 s−1, Airgas) supplied using a mass flow controller (MKS) and held for 2 h to reduce the sample. The samples were cooled to 308 K in flowing 10 % H2/Ar. After the samples were cooled, N2 gas supplied using a digital mass flow controller (MFC, Aalborg) was flowed into the cell at 308 K and a background scan was taken. 5 % CO/Ar (Airgas) was flowed into the cell at 0.5 cm3 s−1 and spectra were collected until the spectra were invariant. Next, weakly bound CO was removed by flowing N2 (0.5 cm3 s−1, UHP, Airgas), and spectra were collected until the spectra were invariant. 2.2.6 Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR) Post-reaction analysis of reaction products using 11B NMR was done using a Bruker NEO 500 MHz spectrometer with Cryoprobe. Post reaction solutions were separated from the spent catalysts and dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide-d6 (D,99.9 %, Cambridge Isotope Laboratories Inc.) and the spectra was collected at a frequency of 500 MHz. 2.3 Kinetic measurements Catalysts (0.018–0.02 g) were loaded into a two-necked glass reactor that was equipped with a reflux condenser and placed within a mineral oil bath sitting on a hot plate with magnetic stirring (Supplier). Gas flows were fed into the system using mass flow controllers (MKS) which supplied the system with argon (3.25 cm3 s−1, 99.999 % Airgas). The catalyst powders were mixed with 5 cm3 of CH3OH (Sigma Aldrich, 99.9 %) and the reactor headspace was purged with flowing argon while the system was heated to the desired reaction temperature. The reflux condenser cooled by a 50/50 v/v mixture of de-ionized water and ethylene glycol was maintained at 268–273 K to avoid methanol loss due to evaporation during each experiment. The reactor outlet was analyzed using an online mass spectrometer (MKS Cirrus 3). After the mass spectrometer signals stabilized, the reaction was initiated by injecting 5 cm3 of an AB/methanol solution into the reactor. Reaction was considered complete when the H2 gas signal returned to the baseline level. Calibration curves between the H2 flow rate and the MS output signal were generated to quantify the total moles of H2 produced during the reaction. Varying amounts of H2 (99.999 %, Airgas) were fed along with a set flowrate of Ar to construct the calibration curve for evolved H2 produced during the reaction. Calibration curves for H2 were constructed at range of different stream flow rates of argon (0.92–3.33 cm3 s−1) to examine the effect of sweepstream flow rate on H2 formation rate. Initial H2 formation rates were estimated by calculating the highest initial H2 flow rate measured during the reaction and normalizing that value by the moles of ruthenium in the catalyst sample. The mole balance equations used to determine H2 formation rates are shown in Eqs. The AB conversion (XAB) was estimated by calculating the total moles of H2 formed during the reaction and dividing it by the total H2 moles in the initial AB solution, assuming three moles of H2 per mol AB initially (Eq. (4) . Rates per surface Ru were quantified using dispersions estimated from particle size distributions measured by TEM. We note that these dispersions may be slightly different than those estimated by probe molecule chemisorption, and that chemisorption measurements are prone to inaccuracy for Ru catalysts prepared from RuCl3, as residual Cl can inhibit H2 chemisorption [40], and Ru is prone to corrosion by CO [41]. Estimates of ruthenium dispersion using H2 chemisorption, CO chemisorption, and H2-O2 titration were deemed to be unreliable and inaccurate due to the small observed particle size range and potential effects of chlorine contamination for H2 chemisorption and H2-O2 titration, and adsorption stoichiometry in the case of CO chemisorption [42–44]. As particle sizes were similar across all samples studied here, and particle size distributions similarly narrow across all samples studied here, the average particle size from TEM was used to estimate the Ru dispersion for each sample, in order to allow for comparison of reactivity on a per surface Ru atom basis. Given the similar dispersions and weight loadings of all samples, similar trends would be obtained if instead rates per mol Ru or rates per mass catalyst were compared instead. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of support Ru catalysts Catalyst samples were characterized by N2 physisorption, ICP-OES, XRD, TEM, pulsed H2 chemisorption, and CO DRIFTS, with results reported in Table 1 . Surface area varied widely across the samples tested, most notably for the Ru/C sample whose surface area was 1470 m2 g−1, whereas the oxide-supported catalysts had surface areas ranging from 84-420 m2 g−1. Ru loadings from ICP-OES were generally consistent with targets from IWI. XRD patterns are shown in Fig. S1 in the supporting information. The peaks observed in each of the patterns are from each catalyst support. Representative TEM images for the various samples are reported in Fig. 1 . Particle size distributions from TEM indicate that particle sizes were ∼1.5–2 nm for all samples, resulting in Ru dispersions ranging from 0.62 to 0.88. The absence of diffraction peaks for Ru in the XRD patterns is consistent with the small particle sizes observed by TEM. CO DRIFTS was used to probe the surface Ru sites present and compare across samples prepared on various supports (Fig. 2 ). These spectra included bands for CO bound to metallic Ru (2030 cm−1), CO bound to Ruδ+ (2080 cm−1), and multiply bound CO at Ruδ+ (2137 cm−1) consistent with similar observations in the literature [45–47]. Small shifts in the band centers corresponding to adsorbed CO species were observed for all supports shown in Fig. 2. The single adsorbed CO species on partially reduced ruthenium observed at around 2080 cm−1 had the highest intensity on Ru/SiO2; the amount of these sites has been shown previously to depend on the nature of the support [48]. Both Ru/Al2O3 and Ru/TiO2-SD had higher amounts of Ru0-CO compared to Ru/SiO2. After removal of weakly bound CO in flowing inert gas, the band corresponding to the multicarbonyl species on partially oxidized ruthenium for Ru/Al2O3 was completely removed, which was not observed for the other supports (Fig. 2 ). 3.2 Kinetic measurements H2 release from AB was measured in a semi-batch reactor with a continuous stream of Ar passing through the headspace of the reactor. The contribution of any solution-phase Ru (for example, if Ru were to leach to solution) to the observed H2 release was excluded on the basis of hot filtration tests that showed the H2 release from the supernatant following reaction was comparable to that observed in the absence of catalyst ( Fig. S3 ). Initial rates were measured across range of Ar sweep stream flowrates, in order to confirm that these values were invariant with flowrate as would be expected assuming plug flow from the surface of the liquid to the mass spectrometer. Across all these data, the total amount of H2 released was relatively constant (see Fig. S4b ), suggesting the variation in initial H2 release rate was merely due to mixing within the headspace of the reactor or the condenser en route to the mass spectrometer. To probe the influence of hydrodynamics on the measured reaction rate, H2 evolution rates measured at varying residence times were regressed using a linear relation shown in Fig. S4a . The rates measured at an Ar flowrate of 3.25 cm3 s−1 were extrapolated to zero residence time using this relation, which resulted in the reported rates being 32% greater than their measured values. Additionally, these effects were verified to be directly as a result hydrodynamics by examining the residence time distribution in the reactor and quantification of the system Peclet number to examine the effects of axial dispersion in the headspace and downstream volumes of the reactor apparatus, as shown in Section S.6 of the supporting information. The rapid transport of the products to the mass spectrometer implied by the results of Fig. S6 indicate that the accumulation of H2 in the reactor headspace is negligible, and thus that the impact of equilibrium limitations (caused by reverse reactions due to non-negligible H2 concentrations) is likely negligible. The reaction thermodynamics imply the potential impact of equilibrium limitations based on calculation uncertainties [31]. The impact of H2 in the headspace was probed via an experiment wherein 0.16 cm3 s−1 H2 was fed into the reactor during the reaction. The measured initial rate was nearly identical to the same condition in the absence of hydrogen, indicating that equilibrium limitations do not impact this system ( Fig. S18 ). Similar estimates of Peclet number were obtained for the H2 flow rates during reaction (with varied Ar sweepstream flowrate) and for pulses of air (with varied Ar sweepstream flowrate) used to probe the residence time distribution in the reactor headspace and downstream volumes ( Fig. S5 ). A 32% correction was applied to all measured initial rates reported in this manuscript, which were collected with an Ar sweep stream flowrate of 3.25 cm3 s−1. The influence of axial dispersion on H2 transport were also ruled out by comparisons to the residence time distribution and observed H2 signals during measurements as shown in Section S.6 of the Supporting Information [49]. The H2 rates were collected based on the highest initial observed H2 flow rate. At lower initial AB concentrations (e.g., 0.025 M), the AB conversion was 25% at the time the initial rate was measured, and the AB conversion at which rates were measured decreased to ∼ 10% as the initial AB concentration increased ( Fig. S7 ). The initial rate was measured as a function of the stir rate, to ensure a lack of external mass transfer limitations. Rates and total amounts of H2 released were invariant with stir rate ( Fig. S8 ), thus it was assumed that external mass transfer limitations did not impact measured initial rates. The relevance of internal mass transfer limitations was probed by calculating the Weisz-Prater criterion, using reported values for methylamine diffusion coefficients [50] as a proxy for AB diffusion coefficients [51]. This calculation is reported in Section S.9, and suggest that for all initial AB formation rates this study other than those over Ru/TiO2 at 343 K (e.g., initial AB formation rates lower than 8.34 mol H2 (mol Ru)-1 s−1), internal mass transfer limitations are unlikely to impact measured rates. The apparent activation energy for H2 release from AB was measured at 0.1 M AB concentration across the series of samples (Fig. 3 ). Possible explanations for this non-linearity at higher temperatures could include higher AB conversions at higher temperatures, impacts of products on measured rates at higher AB conversions, change in rate determining step at higher temperature, and increasing relevance of internal diffusion limitations at elevated reaction temperatures. We exclude the first two possibilities, as the highest conversion in these data was 20 %, which is not significantly different from the data points in the linear region (highest conversion of 22 %), such that reactant depletion and product accumulation are not substantially different in the low and high temperature regimes. We cannot exclude the possibility of a change in rate determining step, though we expect it is more likely that the decrease in slope on these Arrhenius plots results from an increased relevance of internal diffusion limitations, which are difficulty to accurately exclude given the lack of diffusivity data for AB in methanol available in the literature. Nevertheless, Eapp would be expected to decrease by 50% if internal diffusion became limiting, and the change in slope in Fig. 3 would be consistent with such a decrease. As such, we report Eapp values using only the low temperature linear portion of these plots, from 273-318 K. Resultant activation energies are reported in Table 2 and ranged from 24-34 kJ mol−1. These values are comparable to some of those reported in literature for AB decomposition on supported ruthenium catalysts. The measured apparent activation energies range from 24-33 kJ mol−1, which suggest that external diffusion limitations do not limit measured initial rates, as diffusion rates through external boundary layers depend weakly on temperature, resulting in measured Eapp of ∼0–5 kJ mol−1 when external diffusion is limiting [52]. For example, for AB methanolysis over Ru/montmorillonite (MMT; 24 kJ mol−1, [37]) and for AB hydrolysis over Ru/TiO2 and RuNi/TiO2 (38 and 28 kJ mol−1, respectively [53]). However, the Eapp for AB methanolysis over Ru/C in this work (33 kJ mol−1) was lower than that reported previously (54 kJ mol−1 , [36]). Further, other studies of AB hydrolysis over Ru/TiO2 and Ru/Al2O3 reported apparent activation energies of 70 kJ mol−1 [20] and 58 kJ mol−1 [54], respectively. The activation energies shown in Table 2 are calculated from the initial H2 release rates measured at temperature ranging from 273-318 K. Literature estimates for Eapp on Ru/SiO2 were similar to those observed on Ru/MMT [37] which was estimated using the first order rate constants from measurements at 0.14 M AB in a temperature range of 293–313 K. Over Ru/C, the Eapp was observed to be 33 kJ mol−1, distinct from that reported for AB methanolysis on Ru/graphene when Eapp was measured from 283-293 K (54 kJ mol−1 [36]), however those data were collected at a higher AB concentration (3.2 M) than was used in this work. Comparing the initial rates of the various samples at 273 K (0.1 M AB), it is apparent that all samples have similar rates (within a factor of 3) (Fig. 4). Residual Cl is reported to be present after samples prepared from RuCl3 are reduced at 573 K [40]. To probe any impacts of residual Cl on the measured rates, we prepared two Ru/Al2O3 samples using either ruthenium chloride or ruthenium nitrate as the Ru source. The H2 release rate per surface ruthenium over the catalyst prepared with ruthenium chloride was similar to that prepared by ruthenium nitrate, which suggests blocking of surface Ru sites by residual Cl in samples prepared from RuCl3 did not substantially impact activity ( Fig. S9 ). As the reduction temperature was constant across all samples prepared from RuCl3 in this study (573 K), and the resultant particle sizes were all similar (Fig. 1 , Table 1), it is likely that any potential roles of residual Cl are similar across all samples prepared from RuCl3 in this study. Ammonia borane dehydrogenation has been studied over a wide range of supported noble metal nanoparticles [6]. In terms of AB hydrolysis, transition metal oxides (CeO2, TiO2, Al2O3, zeolites) are among the most widely used for supports [55]. Akbayrak et al. [56], observed exceptionally high activity (TOF = 33.5 s−1, per mol Rh, 0.1 M, 298 K) on ceria supported Rh, with the high activity attributed to the reducibility of ceria, creating a high concentration of negative charge on the surface, in turn binding the Rh more strongly. Carbon-based supports are used frequently for their high surface areas and have similar TOFs as metal oxide supports [55]. Carbon-based supports have also been reported with Ru/graphene [25] and Ru/carbon black [57] having reported turnover frequencies of 10 s−1 (per mol Ru, 298 K) and 7.2 s−1 (per mol Ru, 298 K, and 0.2 M AB), respectively. Carbon-based supports offer a lower cost and stable option for a support with high surface area and comparable activity in AB dehydrogenation [58,59]. Electronic effects of the support have been shown also to be important for carbon-based supports, for example, over Pt/CNT where defect rich carbon nanotubes had higher initial rates (6.9 mol H2 (mol Pt)-1 s−1 vs. 2.4 mol H2 (mol Pt)-1 s−1 , 303 K, 0.065 M AB) than pristine carbon nanotubes [60]. Methanolysis of AB is studied less extensively in the literature, but Ru/graphene and Ru/MMT have been reported, with TOFs of 1.7 s−1 and 2.0 s−1 (per surface Ru, 0.1 M AB, 273 K) respectively [36,37]. From these comparisons, it is apparent that for these materials under these conditions, the initial TOF was on the order of ∼1–2 s−1 across all samples, suggesting that methanolysis TOFs over Ru nanoparticles are not strong functions of the identity of the support (see Fig. 4 ). As CO showed multiple features for CO bound to Ru, in varied proportion from sample to sample, spectra were deconvoluted to determine the relative areas for each component for each sample ( Fig. S10 ). H2 formation rates were compared as a function of the relative area for each species in these spectra, as shown in Fig. S10 . Of these, the observed rates correlated best with the proportion of Ru0, whereas the rate correlated less strongly with the abundance of the partially oxidized ruthenium species. However, even the correlation with the abundance of Ru0 was weak (R2 = 0.40), as such we report rates normalized per surface Ru (from TEM), and not based on the abundance of any species observed by CO DRIFTS. Ammonia borane hydrolysis mechanisms have been reported in the literature, with the rate limiting step being the breakage of the of the O–H in the H2O molecule [61], which is consistent with measured kinetic isotope effect (KIE) values comparing H2O to D2O solvent [62,63]. Chen et al. [62] proposed a similar mechanism on Pt/CNT catalysts with the scission of the O–H bond in the adsorbed H2O molecule being the rate determining step. Xu et al. [64] proposed that the formation of an activated complex between the metal particle on the surface and the AB molecule leads to a concerted breakage of the dative B-N bond and hydrolysis of the BH3 molecule (Scheme 2 ). This conclusion was based on ammonia borane hydrolysis measurements and 11B NMR experiments performed on product solutions from measurements on supported Cu, Ni and Co based catalysts [64]. The formation of the aforementioned activated complex with ammonia borane and the metal was proposed as the rate determining step, which may not hold for AB methanolysis, in which isotopic labeling experiments demonstrated a primary KIE from replacement of CH3OH with CD3OD of 5.78 and a KIE from replacement of NH3BH3 with NH3BD3 of 1.29 [32]. If adsorbed BO2 (i.e., BO2*) formed from AB hydrolysis is anionic, this species would be isoelectronic to CO2, which potentially could be a thermodynamically favorable final state for the reaction products [65]. The presence of oxidized boron species observed in our 11B NMR in experiments (see Fig. S14 ) and in the literature [10,66], indicates that the final state of the products favors [BO2]- instead of CO2. Alternatively, the mechanism for AB hydrolysis could proceed via the adsorption of water (Scheme 3 , step 1) and dissociative adsorption of AB (Scheme 3, step 2) and water, followed by the rate-determining dissociation of the O–H bond in H2O (Scheme 3, step 3), liberation of the H atoms from the cleavage of the B-H and O–H bonds to form NH3BH2(OH)* (Scheme 3, step 3), and release of the first equivalent of H2. Subsequent equivalents of H2 are then evolved when the adsorbed NH3BH2(OH)* species reacts with a second H2O molecule (Scheme 3, step 4), the sequential hydrolysis of the AB species continues until the third H2 molecule is released [67]. The KIE comparing H2O to D2O solvent was 1.9, which indicates the cleavage of the O–H bond is kinetically relevant [68]. It has been suggested that the H atoms from the boron side of the molecule form the released H2 during the reaction based on the observed H/D KIE for NH3BH3 and NH3BD3 [32], we note that the B-H bonds are stronger than the N–H bonds in AB [69]. However, previous observations KIE measurements and 11B NMR as mentioned previously demonstrate the kinetic relevance of the O–H bond cleavage in addition to the involvement of the BH3 group [10,68]. Post-reaction NMR after AB methanolysis revealed two different boron species potentially present after H2 release ran to completion. The peaks in the spectra at ∼20 and ∼15 ppm likely correspond to a B(OR)3 species and a (RO)2BH species respectively ( Fig. S14 ) [70], consistent with the structure of a terminal product expected from repeated methanolysis of AB. Reporting on the mechanism of AB methanolysis is more limited than that regarding ammonia borane hydrolysis. AB methanolysis has been reported to involve the cleavage of the OH bond in methanol, based on KIE measurements of NH3BH3 vs. NH3BD3 reactants (1.29) and CH3OH/CD3OD solvents (5.78) on Ru encapsulated inside porous N-doped carbon at 298 K [32]. Kang et al. [71] observed similar measured KIE values for CD3OD and CH3OD relative to CH3OH (2.2 and 3.4) for AB methanolysis on AuPd@ZIF-8. Liao et al. [72] measured the KIE of CH3OH compared to CH3OD, which was 3.12. Based on literature observations and proposed mechanism (Scheme 4 ) for ammonia borane hydrolysis we propose the following mechanism for AB methanolysis on Ru-supported nanoparticles. Based on the data reported here, the state of the hydrogen (e.g., proton, radical, hydride) is not discernable, but assuming it originates from the BH3 group (Scheme 4), it is most likely hydridic [4]. The methanolysis of AB begins with the adsorption of the CH3OH molecule on a site followed by the irreversible dissociative adsorption of the AB molecule on two different adjacent sites (Scheme 4, steps 1–2). The adsorbed CH3OH molecule reacts with the NH3BH2 to form NH3BH2(OCH3); this step is assumed to be rate-limiting for this mechanism (Scheme 4, step 3). The liberated H adatoms on the surface then associatively desorb as H2 (Scheme 4, step 6). Steps 4–5 in the mechanism are assumed to be fast and kinetically irrelevant for the development of the rate equation. Assuming the rate determining step is Step 3 from Scheme 4 and the [ C H 3 O H ∗ ] and [ N H 3 N H 2 ] are the most abundant surface intermediates (MASI) for the mechanism results in the following rate equation (Eq. (5) , additional details about the derivation are present in Section S.11 of the supporting information. This equation will be referred to as “model 1” for subsequent sections. (5) r H 2 L = k 2 [ N H 3 B H 3 ] K 1 C H 3 O H + k 2 N H 3 B H 3 k 3 K 1 C H 3 O H 2 H2 release rates were measured as a function of concentration, and a simplified two step mechanism was used to derive a simple rate law, with rate and equilibrium constants regressed for all supports and are reported in Table 3 . These regressions are shown as dashed lines in Fig. 5 and capture the trends across all supports (residual plots are reported in the Supporting Information, Section S.13). Rate expressions do not include product concentrations, as all initial rates were measured at conversions < 20 % for 0.05–0.8 M AB with 0.025 M AB having a measured conversion of 30 %, where product concentrations were assumed to be neglible relative to methanol and AB concentrations. These results generally indicate that the higher observed reactivities for Ru/TiO2 and Ru/C relative to Ru/SiO2 and Ru/Al2O3 result from slightly higher effective rate constants, and slightly lower equilibrium constants for adsorption of AB (or AB-derived intermediates). Parameter estimates for the regressions of the rate equation to the data in Fig. 5 are tabulated in Table 3. The model predictions for the equilibrium constant (K1) for methanol adsorption were similar in value between each of the catalysts, indicating a similar degree of methanol adsorption on the catalyst surface. The forward rate constant (k2) for dissociative NH3BH3 adsorption was higher for Ru/SiO2 and Ru/Al2O3 compared to the Ru/C and Ru/TiO2-SD catalysts indicating that AB more rapidly adsorbs to the surface on the former two catalysts. The rate constant (k3) for the rate-determining reaction of the adsorbed methanol and dissociated AB (Table 3) correlated well with the differences in measured initial rates for all catalysts (Fig. 5); the highest initial rates were observed on Ru/C and Ru/TiO2. However, model 1 does not accurately capture the rate as a function of AB concentration for Ru/C, Ru/Al2O3, and Ru/SiO2. Measurements of AB methanolysis with higher concentrations of AB (0.8 M, Fig. 5) on Ru/SiO2 and Ru/TiO2 resulted in two distinct trends, as the rate decreased on Ru/TiO2 between 0.4–0.8 M AB and remained approximately constant in this concentration regime for Ru/SiO2. As a result, an additional series of elementary steps and resultant rate expression were developed to capture the trend on Ru/SiO2. A single-site rate equation was derived from a series of elementary steps that better capture the trends with the rate versus concentration trends on Ru/Al2O3, Ru/C, and Ru/SiO2. Scheme 5 describes a series of elementary steps in an alternative proposed mechanism for the methanolysis of AB. The mechanism begins with the reversible adsorption of methanol to the catalyst surface on a single site (Scheme 5 , Step 1). Ammonia borane adsorbs at the same site as the bound methanol molecule, forming a methanol-AB complex (Scheme 5, Step 2). The O–H bond in the methanol molecule and one B-H bond in the AB break to form an equivalent of H2 which for this mechanism was assumed to be the rate-determining step (Scheme 5, Step 3). Steps 4–5 in Scheme 2 are assumed to be fast and kinetically irrelevant. The rate equation for this mechanism is shown in Eq. (6) with the associated derivation shown in Section S.11 of the Supporting Information. This equation will be referred to as “model 2” in subsequent sections. (6) r H 2 L = K 1 ′ K 2 ′ k 3 ′ C H 3 O H [ N H 3 B H 3 ] 1 + K 1 C H 3 O H + K 1 ′ K 2 ′ N H 3 B H 3 [ C H 3 O H ] Regression of the rate as a function of concentration to Eq. (6) predict equilibrium constants for methanol adsorption ( K 1 ′ ) that indicated that the strength of methanol binding was similar across all catalysts (Table 3). The values for K 2 ′ and k 3 ′ for AB adsorption and AB dehydrogenation from model 2 were less consistent with measured rates compared to the previous model for AB adsorption (Table 3). Parameter estimates for both the Ru/C and Ru/Al2O3 lead to predicted values for k 3 ′ being higher on Ru/Al2O3 when compared to Ru/C, which runs contrary to regression of parameters in Eq. (5) . K 2 ′ and k 3 ′ estimates for both Ru/TiO2-SD and Ru/SiO2 differ from estimates on the other two catalysts substantially, this likely is due to the addition of higher concentration data points in those regressions; for both of these catalysts the regressions resulted in similar values for both the equilibrium constant for AB adsorption ( K 2 ′ ) and the forward rate constant for AB dehydrogenation ( k 3 ′ ) . The apparent first order rate constants from model 1 and model 2 ( k app 1 and k app 2 ) are compared in Table 3 along with the parameter estimates for both models. For both model 1 and model 2, the predicted value for the apparent first order rate constants was similar for all catalysts (within 39% for model 1, and within 50% for model 2). This indicates that at low AB concentrations, the reactivity of the four samples is similar to one another. As the concentration increased beyond 0.1 M AB, the model predictions diverged from experimental rates for all catalysts. The sums of squared errors for model 1 and model 2 are tabulated in ( Table S1 , Section S.17) of the Supporting Information. For the Ru/SiO2, and Ru/Al2O3 catalysts, the sums of squared errors were an order of magnitude lower for model 2 compared to model 1. Ru/C had similar sum of squared errors for both models. For Ru/TiO2, the sum of squared errors was two times greater for model 2 compared to model 1. While each model captures the trends in the initial rate at low AB concentrations, both models diverged in their predictions at higher concentrations (Fig. 5). In conclusion, the rate versus concentration trends were regressed based on two different mechanisms with their two respective derived rate expressions (Eq. (5) and Eq. (6) . Model 1 represents a mechanism involving dissociative adsorption of NH3BH3 with the rate limiting step being the H abstraction from an adsorbed CH3OH molecule. Model 2 describes a single-site mechanism with the AB dehydrogenation occurring through the reaction of an adsorbed CH3OH molecule with a NH3BH3 molecule in the bulk solvent. The regressed parameters of model 1 more accurately reflected the trends in initial rate measurements on Ru/TiO2-SD but resulted in higher sums of squared errors for the data for Ru/C, Ru/Al2O3, and Ru/SiO2. Regression of the rate versus concentration data to the single-site rate equation (Eq. (6) resulted in a better representation of the trends in Ru/C, Ru/Al2O3, and Ru/SiO2. Comparing the apparent first order rate constants for each model on each catalyst indicates that both models can sufficiently describe the trends at low concentrations, additionally the values for k app 1 and k app 2 highlight that there are minor differences between the catalytic activity for all measured catalysts. Both models predict that methanol adsorbs to a similar degree on all catalysts (Table 3). In the case of model 1, NH3BH3 adsorbs much faster on Ru/Al2O3 and Ru/SiO2 compared to Ru/TiO2-SD and Ru/C (K2, Table 3). At lower concentrations of AB, the differences in the measured rates between at catalysts was the lowest and predictions from both models were similar (Fig. 5). At higher concentrations of AB the model predictions for models 1 and 2 and the measured rate diverged between each catalyst. For model 1, the k 3 values were highest over Ru/C and Ru/TiO2-SD which was consistent with higher observed rates at concentrations greater than 0.4 M on all catalysts. In the case of model 2, the values for k 3 ′ did not mirror differences in initial rates at high AB concentrations like predicted values for k 3 (Table 3). Comparing the values from model 2 as the product between the equilibrium constants and rate constants for the relevant reaction steps ( K 1 ′ ∗ K 2 ′ ∗ k 3 ′ ) results in values for each catalyst being: 717 (Ru/C), 802 (Ru/SiO2), 832 (Ru/TiO2), and 832 (Ru/Al2O3) ( mol H 2 ( mol surface Ru ) - 1 CH 3 OH - 1 NH 3 BH 3 - 1 s - 1 ). This reinforces the fact that these catalysts are all kinetically similar according to predictions via model 2 and model 1. Model 2 resulted in reduced sums of squared errors from the data for all catalysts except for Ru/TiO2-SD and Ru/C ( Table S1 ). It is likely that the proposed quantities as descriptors of reactivity proposed by these two models are not complete in describing the differences in measured rates between the tested catalysts. These findings indicate that the concentration dependence of the initial AB methanolysis rate is sufficiently described by two different rate equations derived from a series of elementary steps that are consistent with literature observations. These findings suggest that both proposed models are indistinguishable from one another and would require additional measurements at higher concentrations for clearer predictions in the higher concentration range. 3.3 Reuse testing Next, we studied the stability of Ru catalysts through two routes. First, we compared the initial rates of H2 release at various AB concentrations (data points in Fig. 5 panels (a)–(d)) to the instantaneous H2 release rate at various AB concentrations during AB release from a 0.4 M AB solution (solid lines in Fig. 5, panels (a)–(d). The difference between these data indicates the amount of deactivation (or product inhibition) during each transient H2 release experiment and indicates that Ru/C may be the most stable (or least impacted by product inhibition) among the catalysts tested. To further probe the discrepancies between the transient rates and initial rates measured in Fig. 5 , reusability tests were performed on both the Ru/Al2O3 and Ru/C catalysts. After an initial measurement with the fresh catalysts, the powders were recovered from the reaction solution via centrifugation (5000 RPM, 300 s). The supernatant was decanted, and the wet powders were dried for 12 h in a vacuum oven at 303 K (20 mmHg). The initial rates of H2 release over the reused catalyst samples are shown in Fig. 6 . The initial rate decreased for both catalysts in the first reuse. Subsequent uses of the Ru/C catalyst results in no further decrease in reactivity, in contrast to the Ru/Al2O3, which continued to deactivate between the first and second reuse. This is consistent with our conclusions based on transient and measured rates of Ru/C, where the Ru/C initial rates were most similar to the transient rates compared to the other catalysts (Fig. 5). A possible explanation for the greater stability is that product species may not bind as strongly on Ru/C, which would allow for higher rates of product desorption and by extension a catalyst with more resilience over multiple uses. From the reactivity and reuse results, these findings indicate that carbon-supported Ru catalysts may be preferred for low temperature AB methanolysis. Analysis of post-reaction CO DRIFTS of a spent Ru/TiO2 sample revealed a substantial reduction in the concentration of all three ruthenium species present in the spectrum of the fresh catalyst ( Fig. S13 ). Before the saturation of the catalyst with 5 % CO/Ar (Airgas) the catalyst was reduced in the cell for 7.2 ks at 673 K in flowing 10 % H2/Ar (Airgas). This is consistent with observations for re-use testing on Ru/Al2O3 where subsequent reactions using spent catalysts substantially reduced the activity of the material. The reduction in activity with the first re-use for both the Ru/C and Ru/Al2O3 was the largest reduction in catalytic activity compared to further re-use tests (Fig. 6) and according to observations in Fig. S13 this is likely a result of the active Ru species being rendered inactive because of catalyst reuse. 4 Conclusions Kinetics of AB methanolysis have not been widely reported previously, nor have systematic studies of the impact of the support on Ru catalysts used in AB methanolysis. Here, a series of supported Ru catalysts on varied supports were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation, resulting in relatively monodisperse 1.5–2 nm diameter nanoparticles for each sample. These materials were tested in AB methanolysis in a semi-batch reactor, using an on-line MS to quantify effluent H2 flowrates. The impacts of external and internal mass transfer gradients on the measured rates were excluded. Initial rates of H2 release were measured at a series of headspace sweep stream flowrates, and these data were used to extrapolate from measured rates to rates at zero residence time in the headspace of the semi-batch reactor. Initial TOFs correlated most closely with the relative area of CO bound to Ru0, based on CO DRIFTS spectra over Ru/TiO2, Ru/SiO2, and Ru/Al2O3 which indicates that the high concentration of Ru0 present in Ru/TiO2 is an indicator of catalytic activity in AB methanolysis. The partially oxidized Ru species and multicarbonyl showed no trends with rate among any of the measured catalysts. The post-reaction CO DRIFTS on Ru/TiO2 showed a substantial decrease in the peak areas for all Ru species on the catalyst, consistent with observations in re-use testing where a large reduction in the measured rate was observed after the catalyst was reused once. Apparent activation energies measured across the series of samples varied from ∼24–33 kJ mol−1, and H2 formation rates had a generally positive dependence on AB concentration (from 0-0.4 M AB). Regression of these data indicate that effective rate constants are highest for Ru/TiO2 and Ru/C catalysts, while these two materials have the lowest equilibrium constants for adsorption of AB. These factors result in the Ru/TiO2 and Ru/C samples having the highest TOF for H2 release among the samples tested. Comparison of initial rates at various AB concentrations with the instantaneous H2 release rates during H2 release from 0.4 M AB solutions indicate that Ru/C catalysts maintain higher rates as a function of time than do the oxide-supported Ru catalysts tested here. This result is consistent with reuse testing of Ru/Al2O3 and Ru/C (without intermediate washing), which show continual decreases in the initial rates of H2 release over Ru/Al2O3, while H2 release rate over Ru/C decreases from one use, but not upon subsequent reuses. The results in this manuscript suggest that Ru/TiO2 and Ru/C catalysts provided slightly increased TOFs relative to Ru/SiO2 and Ru/Al2O3 catalysts, although TOFs vary by only a factor of 42% across this series of materials. As Ru/C catalysts were among the most reactive and were the most stable with time or repeated reuses catalysts, Ru/C catalysts are suggested as promising materials for further studies of AB methanolysis. coredata.dc:description: Ruthenium catalysts are promising for the catalytic release of H2 from ammonia borane (AB). The reaction kinetics and the role of the support in the release of H2 from AB in methanol solvent were studied using a series of Ru nanoparticle catalysts on various supports (SiO2, carbon, γ-Al2O3, and TiO2). Catalysts were synthesized using incipient wetness impregnation and solution deposition (SD) methods and characterized using N2 physisorption, X-ray diffraction, inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy, CO diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy, and transmission electron microscopy. The reaction kinetics were examined by measuring initial rates using a semi-batch reactor with a constant flow through the headspace analyzed by online mass spectrometry. The Ru/TiO2-SD and Ru/C catalysts had the highest measured initial rates compared to the Ru/SiO2 and Ru/Al2O3. Measured apparent activation energies were relatively similar between all catalysts. Regression of initial rates as a function of AB concentration was done for two different rate equations derived from two different proposed mechanisms for AB methanolysis. Both mechanisms were able to sufficiently describe trends in H2 formation rate versus concentration at low AB concentrations. However, determination of which of the two proposed mechanisms best captures the trends in the data trends was inconclusive due to the lack of a statistically significant difference between degree-of-fit of the two models. Stability tests showed that Ru/C was less prone to deactivation over repeated use compared to Ru supported on the oxides. This study presents a comprehensive examination of the kinetics of AB methanolysis on different supported Ru catalysts; analysis of reaction mechanisms on all catalysts revealed similar apparent first order rate constants from either proposed kinetic models. This study demonstrates that while the support has relatively little influence on the measured reaction rates, carbon may be a preferred support given the decreased deactivation observed relative to the other supports tested.
